trans-unit.source: Relayed Messaging
trans-unit.target: Relayed Messaging

trans-unit.source: Service Bus Relayed Messaging
trans-unit.target: Service Bus Relayed Messaging

trans-unit.source: This section contains information and guidance about the relayed messaging pattern supported by <token>sb1</token>.
trans-unit.target: This section contains information and guidance about the relayed messaging pattern supported by <token>sb1</token>.

trans-unit.source: At the highest conceptual level, using <token>sb2</token> requires:
trans-unit.target: At the highest conceptual level, using <token>sb2</token> requires:

trans-unit.source: One web service that either possesses a <externalLink><linkText>Shared Access Signature</linkText><linkUri>https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn170477.aspx</linkUri></externalLink> (SAS) key or is trusted by the <token>ac2</token> service to create endpoints and receive and send messages (typically responses but also event notifications) from the <token>sb2</token> endpoint that it creates.
trans-unit.target: One web service that either possesses a <externalLink><linkText>Shared Access Signature</linkText><linkUri>https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn170477.aspx</linkUri></externalLink> (SAS) key or is trusted by the <token>ac2</token> service to create endpoints and receive and send messages (typically responses but also event notifications) from the <token>sb2</token> endpoint that it creates.

trans-unit.source: One client application that either possesses a SAS key or is trusted by the <token>ac2</token> service to send and receive messages (typically requests and responses but also event notifications) at a <token>sb2</token> endpoint.
trans-unit.target: One client application that either possesses a SAS key or is trusted by the <token>ac2</token> service to send and receive messages (typically requests and responses but also event notifications) at a <token>sb2</token> endpoint.

trans-unit.source: There is only one difference between the two web service applications: the first web service possesses a SAS key or is trusted by <token>ac2</token> to create an endpoint—that is, an address, or Uniform Resource Indicator (URI)—with <token>sb2</token>.
trans-unit.target: There is only one difference between the two web service applications: the first web service possesses a SAS key or is trusted by <token>ac2</token> to create an endpoint—that is, an address, or Uniform Resource Indicator (URI)—with <token>sb2</token>.

trans-unit.source: <token>crabout</token> endpoints and addresses and how they are used in <token>indigo1</token> and <token>sb2</token>, see <legacyLink xlink:href="http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=183576" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Specifying an Endpoint Address</legacyLink>.
trans-unit.target: <token>crabout</token> endpoints and addresses and how they are used in <token>indigo1</token> and <token>sb2</token>, see <legacyLink xlink:href="http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=183576" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Specifying an Endpoint Address</legacyLink>.

trans-unit.source: The second web application (the client), however, cannot create, affect, or manage the registered <token>sb2</token> endpoint; instead, it possesses a SAS key or is trusted by <token>ac2</token> to interact with endpoints that are already registered.
trans-unit.target: The second web application (the client), however, cannot create, affect, or manage the registered <token>sb2</token> endpoint; instead, it possesses a SAS key or is trusted by <token>ac2</token> to interact with endpoints that are already registered.

trans-unit.source: Typically, the former type of application is referred to as a <newTerm>service</newTerm> (instead of <newTerm>client</newTerm> or calling application), because without a controlling or managing web service, <token>sb2</token> would have no endpoints with which other web-enabled applications can communicate.
trans-unit.target: Typically, the former type of application is referred to as a <newTerm>service</newTerm> (instead of <newTerm>client</newTerm> or calling application), because without a controlling or managing web service, <token>sb2</token> would have no endpoints with which other web-enabled applications can communicate.

trans-unit.source: Web applications that interact with a pre-existing <token>sb2</token> endpoint are conventionally referred to as web service client applications, because they consume the features available at a registered <token>sb2</token> endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Web applications that interact with a pre-existing <token>sb2</token> endpoint are conventionally referred to as web service client applications, because they consume the features available at a registered <token>sb2</token> endpoint.

trans-unit.source: <token>sb2</token> supports two types of messaging patterns: <newTerm>relayed messaging</newTerm> and <newTerm>brokered messaging</newTerm>.
trans-unit.target: <token>sb2</token> supports two types of messaging patterns: <newTerm>relayed messaging</newTerm> and <newTerm>brokered messaging</newTerm>.

trans-unit.source: The two messaging patterns are discussed in the <link xlink:href="7c51e661-013a-4b5a-8e6c-1a0b8df0bd0e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relayed and Brokered Messaging</link> topic.
trans-unit.target: The two messaging patterns are discussed in the <link xlink:href="7c51e661-013a-4b5a-8e6c-1a0b8df0bd0e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relayed and Brokered Messaging</link> topic.

trans-unit.source: This section provides an overview of the technical features of the <token>sb2</token> relayed messaging pattern, at a high level.
trans-unit.target: This section provides an overview of the technical features of the <token>sb2</token> relayed messaging pattern, at a high level.

trans-unit.source: The following additional topics in this section describe application development with <token>sb2</token> from the point of view of a development lifecycle.
trans-unit.target: The following additional topics in this section describe application development with <token>sb2</token> from the point of view of a development lifecycle.

trans-unit.source: Not every development goal requires starting at any one point in the cycle; if you have to develop a client that invokes a service published by <token>sb2</token>, you do not have to read about publishing a service endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Not every development goal requires starting at any one point in the cycle; if you have to develop a client that invokes a service published by <token>sb2</token>, you do not have to read about publishing a service endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Instead, start with <link xlink:href="3468b3db-91b6-4e76-a5ff-216d4c765d05" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Building an AppFabric Service Bus Client Application</link>.
trans-unit.target: Instead, start with <link xlink:href="3468b3db-91b6-4e76-a5ff-216d4c765d05" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Building an AppFabric Service Bus Client Application</link>.

trans-unit.source: Describes how to build a simple <token>sb2</token> client application and service using the “relay” messaging capabilities.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to build a simple <token>sb2</token> client application and service using the “relay” messaging capabilities.

trans-unit.source: Describes how to build a simple <token>sb2</token> host application that exposes a REST-based interface.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to build a simple <token>sb2</token> host application that exposes a REST-based interface.

trans-unit.source: Describes general programming lifecycles for creating an application that uses <token>sb2</token>.
trans-unit.target: Describes general programming lifecycles for creating an application that uses <token>sb2</token>.

trans-unit.source: Describes all of the <token>sb2</token> <token>indigo2</token> bindings and the standard <token>indigo2</token> bindings to which they correspond.
trans-unit.target: Describes all of the <token>sb2</token> <token>indigo2</token> bindings and the standard <token>indigo2</token> bindings to which they correspond.

trans-unit.source: Describes how to design an <token>indigo1</token> service contract that can be registered to be available on at a <token>sb2</token> endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to design an <token>indigo1</token> service contract that can be registered to be available on at a <token>sb2</token> endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Describes how to configure an application that uses <token>indigo2</token>.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to configure an application that uses <token>indigo2</token>.

trans-unit.source: Describes how to make a <token>sb2</token> application more secure.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to make a <token>sb2</token> application more secure.

trans-unit.source: Describes how to set up a <token>indigo2</token> service for hosting.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to set up a <token>indigo2</token> service for hosting.

trans-unit.source: Describes how to build a client application that connects to and uses a <token>sb2</token> service endpoint to communicate with the originating service.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to build a client application that connects to and uses a <token>sb2</token> service endpoint to communicate with the originating service.

trans-unit.source: Describes how to use the <token>sb2</token> service registry to register service endpoints, expose them in the registry, publish WSDL metadata exchange endpoints, and locate service endpoints that have been registered to be publicly visible.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to use the <token>sb2</token> service registry to register service endpoints, expose them in the registry, publish WSDL metadata exchange endpoints, and locate service endpoints that have been registered to be publicly visible.
